videos.title: Blame Danny: Welcome to the Marji Gesick 100
videos.description: Travel Marquette presents, “Blame Danny: Welcome to the Marji Gesick 100” – a film by Aaron Peterson. “Blame Danny” features Peterson's trademark style which blends a mix of storytelling methods and themes to simultaneously capture the action of the Marji Gesick 100 mile mountain bike and running race, the value of the outdoor recreation infrastructure around Marquette Michigan, and the history of the area, dating back to an iron ore deal gone wrong between settlers and Native American tribal chief Madjigijig (Marji Gesick).

videos.title: Marji Gesick 2018 - 50 Mile (Full Race)
videos.description:
A brutal race, even at 50 miles. Just over 7,000 ft of climbing. This race starts in Marquette MI and ends in Ishpeming. Surprised myself with a top 50% finish and a lot less pain than the last two years. 

Poke around or watch the whole thing! I might make a summary video, but I hope this video lets you see the parts of marji you are most interested in.

This race tests you, as a result there are a couple F bombs and such in here. Not a good year for pedals and cleats as they seemed to seize into the pedals making it all but impossible to get off. Video doesn't contain roughly 40 minutes of stopping. But ALLL of the riding is otherwise here. The final 15 miles are historically known as basically insane. They seemed to have tamed them down a bit this year with some new singletrack and less hike-a-bike (grateful), but tough regardless. Miles 19-40 seemed more difficult to me, but no section of this race should be underestimated. The race has always had some sections changed to fine tune the masochism level, but this is a good representation of what to expect. The video just simply doesn't portray how steep the climbing is. Lots of granny gear and almost max effort involved. Steep climbs in succession are the name of the game here.

My strategy for this race is to recover whenever possible. Sure, i could go faster in the easy parts, but i'd rather stay on my bike for the climbs as much as possible. I suck at pushing a bike and it's more gratifying for me to make the climbs then possibly finish a little quicker with a bunch of walking (if that's possible?). Strategy worked well for me this year.
